channel.title: miljko tweets
channel.description: A feed of recent tweets from miljko.

item.description: Yes! The answer to expensive RCTs is not patching together a Frankenstein's monster of phase 2 studies, post-hoc Bayesian trawling, "real world" data and machine learning/AI, it is making the thing we know works less expensive. https://t.co/cDtD7pRUcJ
item.source:markdown: Yes! The answer to expensive RCTs is not patching together a Frankenstein's monster of phase 2 studies, post-hoc Bayesian trawling, "real world" data and machine learning/AI, it is making the thing we know works less expensive. https://t.co/cDtD7pRUcJ

item.description: @trishankkarthik @nntaleb Bingo. Employed doctors are RVU generating machines (and if you needed any more confirmation that medicine is not a science, just look up what "RVU" means). They are also one of the few patient-oriented facets of the system and get the brunt of the hate (being the best paid).
item.source:markdown: @trishankkarthik @nntaleb Bingo. Employed doctors are RVU generating machines (and if you needed any more confirmation that medicine is not a science, just look up what "RVU" means). They are also one of the few patient-oriented facets of the system and get the brunt of the hate (being the best paid).

item.description:
@trishankkarthik @nntaleb It's a high-income, low-wealth profession. Expensive to get into (without state-sponsored higher education at least; thank you, Serbia), doesn't start paying off until years after graduation (interns/residents earn just slightly above minimum wage)…

@trishankkarthik @nntaleb …then as soon as you start earning six figures you get barraged with offers for "doctors loans" for that Mercedes and 6-bedroom McMansion you fantasized about during 36hr calls. There would be no medicine if there weren't for people who actually enjoyed doing.

@nntaleb To clarify for those whose reading comprehension is as bad as mine: rich at 35 is not a test of intelligence, it is a test of skills & abilities for being Fat Tony. Not everyone’s goal, of course! Now, if rich at 35 were a test of intelligence, doctors would be dumb as rocks.
item.source:markdown: @nntaleb To clarify for those whose reading comprehension is as bad as mine: rich at 35 is not a test of intelligence, it is a test of skills & abilities for being Fat Tony. Not everyone’s goal, of course! Now, if rich at 35 *were* a test of intelligence, doctors would be dumb as rocks.

item.description: Today in misleading headlines… Though to be fair to FT, authors of the paper were much more relaxed about throwing around arrows of causality in the interview than they were in their own manuscript. https://t.co/bkS7Hz6GX0
item.source:markdown: Today in misleading headlines… Though to be fair to FT, authors of the paper were much more relaxed about throwing around arrows of causality in the interview than they were in their own manuscript. https://t.co/bkS7Hz6GX0

item.description: If there is one byline never to be missed it’s @KatherineEban. Yowza! https://t.co/kmLmI65GHF https://t.co/dIzOP7h4TW

item.description: @scmarco69 @nntaleb @JordanHedberg @NachoOliveras @EconTalker People who get covid vaccines are older than people who get most other vaccines. Second, covid vaccines have increased scrutiny, so I’d expect more reporting in the same age group. When a 70 y/o nursing home resident dies a week after pneumonia shot no one will report it to VAERS
item.source:markdown: @scmarco69 @nntaleb @JordanHedberg @NachoOliveras @EconTalker People who get covid vaccines are older than people who get most other vaccines. Second, covid vaccines have increased scrutiny, so I’d expect more reporting in the same age group. When a 70 y/o nursing home resident dies a week after pneumonia shot no one will report it to VAERS

item.description: @scmarco69 @nntaleb @JordanHedberg @NachoOliveras @EconTalker It’s not the validity of reports that is the issue with VAERS, it is the post hoc ergo propter hoc fallacy. VAERS may be useful for picking up on unique side effects, but for common things like death it is worse than useless.
item.source:markdown: @scmarco69 @nntaleb @JordanHedberg @NachoOliveras @EconTalker It’s not the validity of reports that is the issue with VAERS, it is the post hoc ergo propter hoc fallacy. VAERS may be useful for picking up on unique side effects, but for common things like death it is worse than useless.

item.description: @nntaleb @JordanHedberg @NachoOliveras @EconTalker In his (Russ Roberts') defense, he didn't say that a 30 y/o shouldn't take the vaccine, rather that it's hard to have an intuitive grasp of that kind of information.
item.source:markdown: @nntaleb @JordanHedberg @NachoOliveras @EconTalker In his (Russ Roberts') defense, he didn't say that a 30 y/o shouldn't take the vaccine, rather that it's hard to have an intuitive grasp of that kind of information.

item.description: "If I were going to be gullible about a subject, I would rather pick one that is the least harmful to my future and one that is rewarding to my thirst for aesthetics." https://t.co/dBiJEDotGj
item.source:markdown: "If I were going to be gullible about a subject, I would rather pick one that is the least harmful to my future and one that is rewarding to my thirst for aesthetics." https://t.co/dBiJEDotGj

item.description: @VPrasadMDMPH @UCSF @UCSF_Epibiostat @UCSFMedicine Congratulations! You can finally stop holding back and really speak your mind.

item.description: BA.5: good as clickbait, not so good at causing a massive spike of infections among the already vaccinated, boosted, infected, and/or dead. So if and when a proper scary strain comes, the usual wolf criers will be all out of capital letters and red alert emoji. https://t.co/nWQjh063R0
item.source:markdown: BA.5: good as clickbait, not so good at causing a massive spike of infections among the already vaccinated, boosted, infected, and/or dead. So if and when a proper scary strain comes, the usual wolf criers will be all out of capital letters and red alert emoji. https://t.co/nWQjh063R0
